Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 51106-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2018 
 
 
 
 
Mongolia: Human Settlements Development Program 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Public Communications 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The proposed knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will assist the Human 
Settlements Development Program of the Government of Mongolia to define strategic directions 
for inclusive, green, competitive, and sustainable urban development through the formulation of 
provincial  socioeconomic  and  spatial  development  plans,  and  with  prioritized  legislative, 
technological, and institutional strengthening support. The TA is included in the country operations 
business plan for Mongolia, 2018–2020 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB).1 The TA is aligned 
with ADB Strategy 2030’s operational priorities, especially reducing inequality, tackling climate 
change, making cities more livable, and promoting rural development.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Mongolia's transition from a centrally planned to a market-based economy in 1991 led 
to important changes in its socioeconomic structure. These changes were reflected in the massive 
and continuous migration to urban areas—by 2017, Mongolia's urbanization rate had reached 
71% (2.2 million of a total population of 3.1 million).3  The country-wide migration also led to a 
rapid expansion of substandard ger (traditional tent) areas4 that lack basic urban infrastructure 
and services such as paved roads, water supply and sewerage networks, district heating systems, 
and public space and services. As a result, these ger areas are having serious environmental 
impacts on urban centers through high levels of air, water, and soil pollution. Mongolia's urban 
centers also face high levels of natural disaster risk.5 Some striking features of the current 
Mongolian urban system are the demographic and economic dominance of Ulaanbaatar, the 
capital city, and its significant difference in size compared with the aimag (province) centers. In 
2017, Ulaanbaatar was home to more than 1.46 million people, accounting for 47% of the 
population,  about  two-thirds  of  Mongolia's  gross  domestic  product,  and  66%  of  the  urban 
population. Except for the cities of Darkhan and Erdenet (each with about 80,000 people in 2016), 
the  services  in  urban  areas  across  the  country  are  weak,  unsound,  and  truncated.6 This 
underserves the needs of urban residents; fails to reduce migration to Ulaanbaatar; slows down 
economic  diversification;  and  is  an  obstacle  for  enhancing  inclusive,  green,  resilient,  and 
sustainable economic and social development. 
 
3.  The government faces the complex task to strategically plan its urban development, the 
spatial distribution of the country's population, and its economic activities to optimize the benefits 
of urbanization and economies of agglomeration. The most recent national urban development 
plan was formulated in 1996 as part of the national framework for regional development in 
Mongolia.7 However,  only  some  portions  of  the  plan  were  formalized  and  comprehensive 
solutions aimed to drive the country's future urban development were never implemented. The 
significant changes in its socioeconomic structure, and the partial approval and implementation 
                                                
1  ADB. 2018. Country Operations Business Plan: Mongolia, 2018–2020. Manila. The TA title has been adjusted to 
better reflect its objective. The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 
21 September 2018. 
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
3  United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division. 2017. World Urbanization 
Prospects: The 2017 Revision—Key Findings and Advance Tables. New York. 
4  About 60% of the total population in the case of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city. 
5  Such as floods, severe winters, droughts, dzud (succession of severe winters and droughts), storms, or earthquakes. 
6  Most of the rest of the aimag capitals have a population below 25,000. 
7  The national framework for regional development in Mongolia is laid out in the Regional Development Concept 
(adopted by Parliament in June 2001), the Law on Regionalized Development Management and Coordination 
(adopted by Parliament in May 2003), and the Medium-Term Strategy on Regional Development, 2001–2010 
(adopted by Parliament in June 2003).

2 
of the national framework for regional development made the existing urban development plans 
obsolete. Mongolia is in urgent need to formulate a comprehensive and pragmatic approach to 
tackling the current socioeconomic and spatial development challenges, such as unbalanced 
territorial development and lack of attractiveness for investments. Such a new approach should 
aim to provide livable urban environments, boost local economic potential, reduce urban pollution, 
provide adequate housing to residents, decrease migration to Ulaanbaatar, strengthen the link 
between urban and rural economies, and mitigate climate change impact. 
 
4.  In response to the need for an updated urban development master plan, the government 
formulated a program that aims to define short-, medium-, and long-term strategic directions for 
inclusive, green, competitive, and sustainable urban development in Mongolia. The program will 
include both national and provincial integrated socioeconomic and spatial development plans as 
well as legislative, institutional, and technological reforms. A national committee headed by the 
Prime Minister (chair) and the minister of construction and urban development (vice-chair) will be 
formed to guide the implementation of the program. The national committee will be assisted by a 
standing  office  to  coordinate  activities  across  different  ministries  and  agencies.  An  urban 
development and research institute will also be established under the Ministry of Construction 
and Urban Development (MCUD) to coordinate the work plans of working groups and inputs from 
various stakeholders such as academic and research centers and nongovernment organizations.8 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
5.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: policy environment for urban and land 
development improved (Objective 5, Article 2.1.5, Mongolia Sustainable Development Vision 
2030)9 in support of economic diversification and social stability.10 The TA will have the following 
outcome:  inclusive  and  comprehensive  strategic  directions  for  sustainable  human  spatial 
distribution in Mongolia developed.11 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
6.  Output 1: Provincial development plans formulated. The TA will build on existing 
studies  and formulate a  development-oriented  aimag  plan for  each of the  21  aimags  and 
Ulaanbaatar City. Each plan should be an integrated collaborative planning approach that builds 
up from the local level into a provincial urban development framework, relying on priority actions 
and incentives to achieve the recommended vision, objectives, and strategic directions. It will 
identify desirable development, socioeconomic and environmental objectives, and pragmatic 
solutions to achieve them. It will help MCUD and local governments in decision-making to drive 
the  socioeconomic  and  environmentally  sustainable  development  of  each  aimag;  and  will 
collectively reflect and support the need and aspiration of the people and business community. It 
will cover three main aspects: a planning framework used by aimags in preparing their general 
                                                
8  Several related studies were carried out by the government and various donors to serve as the foundation for the 
Human  Settlements  Development  Program,  especially  the  Mongolia  National  Urban  Assessment,  2017 
(unpublished) by ADB; and Japan International Cooperation Agency. 2017. Data Collection Survey on Regional 
Comprehensive Development in Mongolia. http://open_jicareport.jica.go.jp/pdf/12285466.pdf. 
9 State Great Khural of Mongolia. 2016. Objective [5] Article [2.1.5] on Mongolia Sustainable Development Vision 2030. 
Ulaanbaatar. 
10 ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Mongolia, 2017–2020—Sustaining Inclusive Growth in a Period of 
Economic Difficulty. Manila. 
11 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
territorial and spatial plans; a policy framework that includes policies, regulations, and institutional 
settings; and development drivers or smart growth features. This will be complemented by a 
human settlement typology, describing the role, function, and potential investment for each type 
of human settlement. The analysis will take into account the role of each aimag within a broader 
regional urban cluster, the low population density of Mongolia, the solutions for redeveloping ger 
areas and achieving affordable housing supply, environmental sustainability, as well as the 
importance of urban–rural links. The data collected for this output will also be incorporated into 
the web-based mapping platform and the e-atlases to be developed under output 4 of the TA. 
 
7.  Output  2:  Integrated  national  strategy  and  policies  for  human  settlement  and 
territorial development co-developed. In collaboration with the Japan International Cooperation 
Agency (JICA), the TA will contribute to the outputs led by JICA in the preparation of the national 
comprehensive development plan of Mongolia. These include the formulation of (i) national 
strategy and policies, and (ii) national and regional socioeconomic and spatial development plans. 
 
8.  Output 3: Relevant national laws and regulations developed. The TA will (i) support 
the amendment of  the existing urban development law and review other pertinent laws and 
regulations, i.e., land law, urban construction law, and urban redevelopment law or regionalized 
development management and coordination law, to ensure that they are aligned with and can 
support the implementation of the national urban strategy; and (ii) help develop guidelines for the 
implementation of the urban development law as well as its effective enforcement. 
 
9.  Output 4: Web-based mapping platform and provincial e-atlases completed. The TA 
will strengthen the existing web-based mapping application developed under the National Urban 
Assessment of Mongolia, 2015–2016 (footnote 7) by providing equipment and training to MCUD 
for developing a mapping system for targeted areas. The mapping system will translate the 
findings of the regional development plans and use satellite maps and statistical mapping as an 
open source to support an evidence-based decision-making process. An e-atlas for each province 
and sub-region of Mongolia will also be produced in both paper-based and electronic versions.12  
 
10.  Output  5:  Program  coordination  capacity  for  urban  planning  and  urban 
development strengthened. The TA will provide capacity-building support to the Standing Office 
of  the  National  Committee  and  the  Urban  Development  Design  and  Planning  Institute  to 
coordinate the program, including but not limited to training programs and workshops, and 
exchange and dissemination of knowledge products and tools. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,150,000, of which $2,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of support staff, meeting facilities, data, topical information 
and government documentation, and other in-kind contributions. Ineligible expenditures include 
the following: pilot activities with no link to ADB-financed operations; activities normally funded 
under ADB loans or ADB budgets for preparation of ADB-financed projects, including TA for these 
activities; preparation of poverty reduction strategy papers and other TA for poverty reduction 
monitoring activities; academic research, land acquisition, motor vehicles purchase, government 
staff salaries, scholarships or long internships, and foreign training or study tours. The key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
                                                
12 For this output, the usage of Spatial Data Analysis Explorer (SPADE), developed jointly by ADB, the European Space 
Agency, the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency, and the University of Tokyo, will be considered.

4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will administer the TA. The Urban and Social Sectors Division of the East Asia 
Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants. Engagement of the consultants and 
procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and 
the associated project administration instructions and staff instructions. The implementation 
arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  December 2018–December 2020 
Executing agency  Ministry of Construction and Urban Development 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
Quality- and cost-based  International  $823,000 
selection method  (39.5 person-months) 
National (135.5 person- $553,000 
months) 
Procurement  To be procured by consultants 
Shopping  2 contracts  $110,000 
Disbursement  The TA resources will be disbursed following ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
Asset turnover or disposal  Equipment will be turned over to the executing agency upon completion of 
arrangement upon TA completion  TA activities. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, TA = technical assistance. 
Source: ADB. 
 
13.  Consulting services. The TA will require tentatively 175 person-months of consulting 
inputs from 10 international experts (39.5 person-months) and 12 national experts (135.5 person-
months).13 A consulting firm will be selected and engaged by ADB under a performance-based 
contract using the quality- and cost-based selection method, with a 90:10 quality–cost ratio and 
full technical proposal procedure.14 Contingencies may be allocated to recruit additional experts 
by the consulting firm or to hire individual consultants based on needs during TA implementation.
 
14.  Cofinancier requirements. A TA letter-signing ceremony with press coverage will be 
organized. To enhance visibility, a representative from the Embassy of Japan in Mongolia will be 
invited. The TA will ensure clear references to the financial contribution of the Government of 
Japan during major project activities and for major outputs (i.e., workshops, publications, press 
releases, and speeches); and use the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and Japan aid logos on 
correspondence, workshop material, banners, and any media publication. The Embassy of Japan 
in Mongolia will be informed about the TA progress, milestones, and deliverables, especially when 
major  changes  in  scope  and  objectives  are  required.  Given  the  proposed  program’s 
interdependence with JICA’s involvement in urban and regional development, close strategic and 
policy cooperation is expected during implementation. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development  Bank  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$2,000,000 to the Government of Mongolia to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for 
Poverty Reduction for the Human Settlements Development Program, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board. 
                                                
13 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
14 The ratio of 90:10 will be adopted because of the complexity of the project design.
